page.title: 17Local History
page.content: Milborne st Andrew Church. The church was built in 1067. It is built of knapped flint and stone. The church is on the south western side of the village and has two fine Norman arches. One is the south porch doorway to the nave, which has a zig-zag ornament of brown and white voussoirs. The other arch is found over the Moreton Chapel on the east wing. Restorations were carried out in 1878 and an early Norman font was found in the churchyard, during 1930. The font has since been placed in the centre of the western aisle. The font is carved from one piece of stone, and its shape is of an imitation water butt, staked with pegs at the base and held with cable at the top. The earliest traceable name of the vicars is 1327 and he was called Thomas De Bucklesworth. There has been 49 since.
